sub_categories.logic: Direct combining using connectors that take a Subject + Verb.
sub_categories.question: The terrain was difficult. The hikers continued their journey.
sub_categories.answer: Although the terrain was difficult, the hikers continued their journey.

sub_categories.logic: Requires transforming a verb or adjective clause into a noun phrase or gerund.
sub_categories.question: She was very tired. She finished the marathon.
sub_categories.answer: In spite of her tiredness, she finished the marathon.

sub_categories.logic: Standard causal linking.
sub_categories.question: It was raining heavily. We cancelled the picnic.
sub_categories.answer: Since it was raining heavily, we cancelled the picnic.

sub_categories.sub_category_name: Cause and Effect – Noun Phrase Takers
sub_categories.logic: Requires transforming the cause clause into a noun phrase.
sub_categories.question: The soccer match was postponed. The weather was bad.
sub_categories.answer: The soccer match was postponed due to the bad weather.

sub_categories.logic: Actions happening at the same time.
sub_categories.question: I was walking to school. I saw a kitten.
sub_categories.answer: While I was walking to school, I saw a kitten.

sub_categories.logic: Requires dropping the subject and converting the first verb to a participle (often 'Having').
sub_categories.question: Ali completed his homework. He went out to play.
sub_categories.answer: Having completed his homework, Ali went out to play.

sub_categories.logic: Requires backshifting tenses and mapping pronouns/time markers.
sub_categories.question: "I am going to the library tomorrow," said Bala.
sub_categories.answer: Bala said that he was going to the library the next day.

sub_categories.logic: Introduces 'if/whether' and requires reordering the subject-verb syntax.
sub_categories.question: "Did you eat the cake?" Mother asked Tom.
sub_categories.answer: Mother asked Tom if he had eaten the cake.

sub_categories.logic: Requires un-inverting the auxiliary verb (Subject-Verb order).
sub_categories.question: "Where is my book?" asked Jane.
sub_categories.answer: Jane asked where her book was.

sub_categories.logic: Converts commands to infinite phrases (to do / not to do).
sub_categories.question: "Please do not touch the exhibit," the guard told us.
sub_categories.answer: The guard requested us not to touch the exhibit.

sub_categories.logic: Object becomes Subject; verb changes to 'be' + past participle.
sub_categories.question: The mechanic is repairing the car.
sub_categories.answer: The car is being repaired by the mechanic.

sub_categories.logic: Subject becomes Object; removal of 'by'.
sub_categories.question: The winning goal was scored by the captain.
sub_categories.answer: The captain scored the winning goal.

sub_categories.logic: The 'Double Negative' trap. Removing 'not' from the conditional clause.
sub_categories.question: If you do not water the plants, they will die.
sub_categories.answer: Unless you water the plants, they will die.

sub_categories.logic: Imaginary situations using 'If I were'.
sub_categories.question: I am not you. I will not accept that offer.
sub_categories.answer: If I were you, I would not accept that offer.

sub_categories.logic: Archaic structure requiring the base form of the verb or 'should'.
sub_categories.question: He walked quietly. He did not want to wake the baby.
sub_categories.answer: He walked quietly lest he wake the baby.

sub_categories.logic: Vocabulary dependent transformation.
sub_categories.question: The boy was curious. He opened the box.
sub_categories.answer: Out of curiosity, the boy opened the box.

sub_categories.logic: Vocabulary dependent transformation.
sub_categories.question: The witness described the burglar. It was very detailed.
sub_categories.answer: The witness gave a detailed description of the burglar.

sub_categories.logic: Fixed phrase structure: 'Much to the [noun]...'
sub_categories.question: John failed the test. He was disappointed.
sub_categories.answer: Much to the disappointment of John, he failed the test.

sub_categories.logic: Ensuring grammatical parallelism on both sides of the conjunction.
sub_categories.question: Mrs Tan is kind. She is also generous.
sub_categories.answer: Mrs Tan is not only kind but also generous.

sub_categories.logic: Testing the Proximity Rule (verb agrees with the nearest noun).
sub_categories.question: James did not go to the party. His friends did not go either.
sub_categories.answer: Neither James nor his friends went to the party.

sub_categories.logic: Past Perfect Tense + Inversion + 'than'.
sub_categories.question: As soon as the bell rang, the students rushed out.
sub_categories.answer: No sooner had the bell rung than the students rushed out.

sub_categories.logic: Inverting the auxiliary verb for emphasis.
sub_categories.question: He did not know that he had won the lottery.
sub_categories.answer: Little did he know that he had won the lottery.

sub_categories.logic: Using 'whom' for people in the object position.
sub_categories.question: That is the man. You met him at the airport.
sub_categories.answer: That is the man whom you met at the airport.

sub_categories.logic: Complex combining involving quantifiers within relative clauses.
sub_categories.question: I have many T-shirts. Some of them are brand new.
sub_categories.answer: I have many T-shirts, some of which are brand new.
